meta.title: Animal Gender: Language Face-Off
meta.description: How do we gender animals in different languages?
meta.others: With Russell Samora, Michelle Pera-McGhee, Jan Diehm

content.value: We recently published a story about how we assign gender to anthropomorphic animals, focusing on English-language children’s books. Across 300 popular books from the past 70+ years, there were some clear patterns. Frogs were overwhelmingly boys. Birds were girls. Pigs leaned a little male but were slowly moving into their Girl Boss era.
Our findings sparked a heated discussion on social media, especially among those who speak languages beyond English. Many people perceived these animals differently.
“Really funny to read this as someone speaking French, a Language Where Everything is Gendered,” one commenter said. “Obviously birds are hes and frogs are shes, what do you mean (haha).”

It’s a great point. Language definitely shapes the way we imagine animals, totally separate from reality or biology. And that may be especially true for Languages Where Everything Is Gendered—aka languages with grammatical gender, where nouns (including animals) are assigned a masculine, feminine, or sometimes neuter gender.

We acknowledged this point in our original story, but you made it clear: for many of you, grammatical gender really shapes your imagined sense of an animal’s gender, even when it’s a made-up character in a kid’s story.

So we wanted to do a quick breakdown of how 10 different languages—Arabic, French, German, Greek, Hindi, Italian, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, and Spanish—gender 14 different animals. How do these animals match up? And how do they compare to our English-language findings?
Animal Face-Off

Let’s start with frogs. Frog characters were almost always gendered male in the popular English-language children’s books that we read. In languages like Arabic, German, Greek, and Hindi, frogs are grammatically gendered male, too.
But in most of the Romance languages—Spanish, French, Portuguese, Italian—frogs are gendered female.
Next up: birds. While birds were one of the few animals gendered more female in the English-language kids’ stories, they are grammatically masculine in 8 of these 10 other languages!
Among these languages, only Russian uses the feminine gender for birds.
Ladybugs are feminine in almost all of these languages, but there’s one curious outlier.

Many words for ladybug around the world have strong associations with femininity—with the Virgin Mary, with “God’s little cow,” and with other female figures (for more on that, see our original story). So a feminine grammatical gender makes some sense.
While the German word for ladybug—Marienkäfer (Mary’s bug)—is also associated with the Virgin Mary, the word is actually grammatically masculine. It’s der Marienkäfer.
We found some examples of German children’s books where ladybug characters are male, something we never found in the popular English-language stories.

content.value: Grammatical gender is not destiny

But, of course, grammatical gender is not destiny. And, in fact, it’s often very arbitrary (in French, the word vagina le vagin is grammatically masculine ¯\_(ツ)_/¯). So even if the word for an animal is grammatically feminine, it doesn’t mean that animal will always be represented as female—or, in the case of anthropomorphic characters, as a girl or a woman.

For example, in Spanish, where frogs are always grammatically feminine (la rana), you still find dude frogs. The famous Muppets character Kermit the Frog is masculinized through the addition of a traditionally male name—La Rana René in Mexico and Latin America, or La Rana Gustavo in Spain.1

There are also other ways of conjuring male frogs, like using the closely related word el sapo (toad). The Spanish translation of Arnold Lobel’s famous Frog and Toad series even uses a totally made up word, sepo—Sapo y Sepo, inseparables—to describe the iconic frog in slacks and distinguish him from his sapo bestie.

value.alt: Book cover of Sapo y Sepo, inseparables. The illustration shows a frog and a toad, one green and one brown, riding a tandem bicycle together. The green frog wears a jacket and pants, while the brown toad wears a cap and shirt.
value.caption: The cover of Sapo y Sepo, Inseparables, the Spanish translation of Arnold Lobel’s Frog and Toad Together, translated by Pablo Lizcano.

content.value: While both these examples are famous male frogs imported from English, you see the same pattern when the stories originate in the same language.
Even though the German word for ladybug is masculine, there are plenty of little girl ladybug characters.
